As many as 90,000 extra tourists per year are being predicted as a result. But one cannot be completely critical of the federal government. Programs such as the regional tourism infrastructure package are actually heading in the right direction. But what rural and regional Australia need is help right now. Future funding committed under federal programs should be brought forward to the forthcoming financial year. Funds earmarked for availability in 2003-04 and beyond should be able to be drawn upon immediately if the programs are ready to proceed.

We are constantly asking Australians to be realistic in their expectations about the viability of certain industries, and we have implored communities to accept that change is inevitable. But this cannot be said of tourism. Much of rural and regional Australia is capable of participating in the tourism revival which is sure to come in the immediate future, and surer to come if programs are put in place to encourage tourism and to enable areas to be viable tourism locations. Even if the international market remains reluctant for a little longer, domestic tourism can be a greater focus in the meantime. Whilst the Australian dollar remains at its current level there is a greater incentive for Australian families to holiday at home. With the picture clearer, albeit somewhat sadder in terms of the domestic aviation market, we can progress with more certainty than in recent months. If ever there was a time for a massive injection of investment and faith in the Australian tourism industry, I think the House and this committee would have to agree that it is certainly now.

All three tiers of government have an opportunity to help all Australians. Government, the business sector and local communities can work together with a common purpose but leadership from the top is required. In Tasmania it is reported that there may be insufficient high quality accommodation to cope with the extra tourists expected. The Chairman of the Launceston Chamber of Commerce, Lloyd Whish-Wilson has already called for better promotion of all areas of Tasmania. But we must also ensure quality. We must also make sure that we can offer the best. In Monday's Launceston Examiner, the Tourism Council of Tasmania's Accreditation Advisory Board Chairman, Mr Damon Thomas, said that new players coming into the tourism industry would need to meet the quality standards expected by interstate and overseas visitors. He quite rightly pointed out that they must do proper research, establish business plans and find out what it is that potential visitors are actually asking for. All three areas of tourism, the holiday market, conferencing and eventsâareas that the Tasmanian industry is very interested inâare capable of providing the basis for renewed growth in rural and regional Australia. For many, a kick-start, seed funding or high quality advice is all that is actually required. But there is no doubt that the most that can be achieved for this vital area can be achieved through a cooperative effort by all partiesâall levels of government and all areas of the industryâand an immediate investment of faith in one industry that can certainly contribute to the revitalisation of rural and regional Australia: tourism.

talk.start.para: âI would like to pay tribute today to a friend of mine, one of the truly great characters of Queensland radio, Colin James Michael Thompson III. He is not really `the Third', but in keeping with his jocular style he claims the title. Col's great love of entertainment commenced as a young man when he joined Chandlers in Elizabeth Street, Brisbane, in their record department. His first appointment to radio was with 4IP Ipswich in the early 1970s, when the concept of `colour radio' was developed by that station and took the Brisbane entertainment market by storm. It was so successful that 4IP had to shift its studios from Ipswich to Brisbane because it had taken so big a share of the Brisbane market.

speech.para: Col was the promotions manager and took that station to a very high level of listenership in the Brisbane market. He was one of the first people to introduce pre-game and half-game entertainment at Rugby League. It is something we take for granted now, with someone singing the national anthem, a lot of dollybirds and other people putting on turns in the arena and lots of other forms of entertainment, but Col was really one of the first who developed that. He has also played a key role in the signing of Jeff Thomson by 4IP and his transfer to cricket in Queensland. He also worked with other famous cricketersâWest Indian cricketers Viv Richards and Alvin Kallicharran. He stayed in this role for 10 years before he moved to the Sunshine Coast. That is where I got to know him in my days with regional development, because one of my duties was with the promotion of the Wide Bay-Burnett areaâwhich was known as Bundaberg and the Coral Isles regionâat Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation promotions.

At that time Col was promoting Pine Trees Resort and lifting the profile of Noosa. Let me say that his team did a remarkable job because from that point forward Noosa has been one of the great magnets of Australian tourism. I can well remember him at the promotions in Sydney and Melbourne as one of the key people who lifted those days when the QTTC actually drove Queensland tourism to an unexpected level, much to the discomfort of all the other states. After many years in this role, he returned to 4BK in Brisbane in a promotion and sales role and later went to 4BH in an executive role.

As recently as 2 March, the Queensland Radio Time Club, which is the peak body of radio in Queensland, inducted Col Thompson into the Radio Hall of Fame at its 27th annual Goldies Award, held at the Brisbane Sheraton. I have had a long association with him, and I think that award was richly deserved. He was not just good for Queensland radio; he was very accomplished in the television area as well. Honourable members would probably remember the coach adsâthe big coach with the shock of blonde hair in the grey sweat jacket revving up the troops to go on the field and sell their Toyota cars. Those ads were so successful that they were done not only in a Rugby League idiom in Queensland but also in an Australian Rules idiom in Adelaide. Col also did a lot of commercials for the Central Queensland areaâ and I see the member for Capricornia hereâthat were also very highly successful. He was one of those people who could bring a team around him and make it work. I suggest that not only the radio industry of Queensland but the television industry of Queensland and the tourist industry owe him a great debt. I think his induction into the Radio Hall of Fame is richly deserved.

talk.start.para: âAnyone who has listened to my speeches in this place over the last three years would know that I am very proud of Rockhampton's title as the beef capital of Australia. Part of the reason for that title is the large meat processing sector that we have in Rockhampton. The meatworks in Rockhampton are a very important source of jobs and economic activity in our region. That is why the current situation, which has seen the Consolidated Meat Group plant at Lakes Creek closed since late last year, is so devastating to our city.

speech.para: The company has given many reasons for the early closure and the failure to reopen the plant, but essentially this is an industrial dispute and one where the company has seen an opportunity to use market conditions to its advantage in negotiations over a new enterprise bargaining agreement. Mr Deputy Speaker, 1,350 people are employed at CMG. That is a very significant number in anyone's terms, especially in a city of 60,000 people. Those workers have now been out of work for four months, and the effect on our city, its economy and local businesses, has been more the effect of a tidal wave than of a ripple.

Thirteen hundred and fifty people and their families mean support for a lot of businesses in Rockhamptonâtheir wages keep a lot of other people employed. Rockhampton already has an unemployment rate well above the national average. The government should be ashamed that it is in double figures and has been for most of the last five years. I know that this government has an appalling record on regional development strategies, but even it should be able to work out that allowing a dispute like this to drag on is doing enormous harm to our region and its ability to focus on the future and seize opportunities.

This has been a huge shock to the CMG work force and their families. The workers at CMG fully expected to return to work after the normal closure period and expected to be back at work by the middle of January this year. They had no hint of the tactics the company was planning. You can just imagine a family going through the normal drain on their budget around Christmas and the holiday period and counting the weeks until they go back to work to relieve some of the pressureâand then the blow comes that there is no work.

There is no time today to go into the government's role in this dispute, although it is clearly a product of the industrial relations regime designed by Peter Reith and supported by the Democrats. Today I want to focus on the workers and their families. There was a community rally in Rockhampton on 2 March. I was very proud to march alongside the meatworkers and their families and the many other supporters who came along from the Central Queensland community. I promised at that rally that I would tell John Howard and Tony Abbott exactly what their unfair industrial relations system is doing to ordinary working families and businesses, big and small, in Rockhampton.

Today there is another event along those lines that I would like to mention. At this very moment, about 60 or so women, both meatworkers and the wives of meatworkers, are having lunch in Rockhampton, to support each other and just for a little while to take their minds off the terrible pressure they are under. The lunch is going on at Bartlett's Tavern, and I would like to say thank you to Gary Ward and his staff for making their very nice facility available for that lunch. They have also organised for a psychologist to speak to the women, to give them ideas about where they can go if the pressure really gets too much for their families. There will also be a financial counsellor there today. The event has been organised by Stephen Dick, Deb and Jim Bronson and Mike Pihama, amongst many others. They are just some of the people who have come together to help the families and the workers overcome the pressures of the last four months. There have also been a lot of other helpers throughout the community, doing things such as collecting grocery items at the various shopping centres and channelling those items through to the local charities, which have been inundated by requests for assistance over the last four months, as you can imagine. The meatworkers are very careful to point out that this is not just for the meatworkers; it is for all those people who have been affected so badly in other businesses throughout Rockhampton as a result of this dispute.

My final message to John Howard and Tony Abbott on behalf of the meatworkers and of those women who are meeting right now in Rockhampton is that, when you attack workers and unionists, you are attacking and hurting family people, community people and the whole community around them.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak about a fantastic program operating in my electorate of Dickson and in electorates right across the country. It is the Work for the Dole program. I had the opportunity last week of visiting a project in this programâthe South Pine River projectâand watching how, in a very practical and real way, it changed the lives of many of the participants and the environment surrounding the Eatons Hill area. It is a credit not only to the Howard government, with the emphasis that they have placed on Work for the Dole, but also to the local operators, including Mission Australia and the Work for the Dole coordinators that have made the program a great success. I presented certificates of completion on that day and took the opportunity to speak to many of the participants. I spoke with them about the very real outcomes that they had achieved through their involvement. It was not just the sense of worth and self-being because of what they had achieved in a very real way on the work, but more so the opportunities and the motivation that it had provided them to go forward and experience new things in life. We hope it will have a positive outcome for them in their future employment.

speech.para: Work for the Dole is helping job seekers improve their work skills and at the same time letting them give something back to their community. Since Work for the Dole was introduced in 1997, more than 7,560 projects have been funded nationally and provided places for more than 157,000 young job seekers. A study into the Work for the Dole program has found that job seekers who had participated in the program had a 76 per cent better chance of finding jobs than those who had not been involved. Work for the Dole is a practical plan that is providing real benefits not only for local job seekers but for the local environment and the district in general. It is another example of the Howard government working to provide a secure future for all Australians.

There are many examples in Dickson of successful Work for the Dole projects. That is quite surprising when you reflect on the last three years of Labor in the seat of Dickson. They were ideologically opposed to the program, despite enormous support for it from the vast majority of constituents in Dickson because they saw the very real outcomes that it provided. But despite that ideological opposition to the Work for the Dole programâprojects were not put forward, they were not supported by the previous Labor member in the seat of Dicksonâ it is amazing that the local community got behind some of the local projects and the outcomes were very real and very tangible for the constituents of Dickson.

Another fine example of a Work for the Dole project in my electorate is the Amy Quinn Handihome. It is a fantastic project that I visited recently. I spoke with the staff there about some of the challenges that they face. The services that they provide in an area of high demand are really a credit to them. Their work was made easier, certainly as much as it can be, by participants from a Work for the Dole project who assisted in outside development programs. I also pay tribute to Amy Quinn herself, a person who has given tirelessly to the Dickson community for many years. That house was named in her honour, and rightly so.

There is also another fine program which has been operating very successfully in Dickson, the Dairy Regional Assistance Program. That has helped the area of Dayboro and the surrounding areas in my electorate to rejuvenate into what is now a burgeoning and very successful regional tourism industry, with the development of some wineries, some bed and breakfasts, horse riding for visitorsâall sorts of things. It is a tribute to the people, particularly the Dayboro Progress Association and the Dayboro community in general, that have made such a fine effort in promoting such a great region.

talk.start.para: âI rise to bring to the attention of the House the outstanding work of a local supported employment training provider in my electorate of Calwell, Brite Industries of Belfast Street in Broadmeadows. Brite is a community based business that provides education and training opportunities for people with disabilities. More recently they have taken it upon themselves to provide training for people who are now known as the vocationally disadvantaged. The Broadmeadows site covers some five acres, with a large factory, a modern warehouse, a plant nursery and training rooms. In February I met with the chief executive officer, Mr Michael Alcock; operations manager, Mr John Wood; and the horticulture manager, Mr Michael Shelley, and I was given a tour of this outstanding site in Broadmeadows. One hundred and fifty-four people are currently employed on site, with 129 of those employees with varying degrees of disability.

speech.para: The federal government subsidy to support Brite workers does not cover all the expenses of running a modern manufacturing site. And Brite Industries is not a charity. It is also not just a sheltered workshop. It is a business with the same commercial considerations as the neighbouring manufacturing sites at Broadmeadows. Chief executive officer, Michael Alcock, describe as follows the primary aim of the organisation:

quote.para: Whilst Brite provides employment for people with disabilities, I also see it as a training and transitional experience leading to open employment.

speech.para: It has successfully supported the transition of more than 80 employees into open employment. The progressive and dedicated management and staff who work there have as their vision the following statement. Again I quote the organisation:

quote.para: Promoting dignity through achievement and community enterprise.

speech.para: They have a mission statement that states:

quote.para: To offer quality training, personal development and community support for people with a disability and people who are vocationally disadvantaged, and to operate commercial businesses for the purpose of generating funds to support and expand its services to the community.

speech.para: Formerly known as Northern Brite Industries, the company is a corporate division of the Victorian Vocational Rehabilitation Association. In its history Brite Industries has been at the forefront of national advances in education and training for people with disabilities. Recently it has expanded its role to take up the challenge of vocationally disadvantaged people. It provides training in a working factory environment, which has given many young people their first taste of working in a fully functional factory. On top of on-site training, Brite offers time release for supported workers to attend TAFE courses. Other employers could learn from the example set by this organisation in its commitment to training.

People with intellectual and physical impairment of a severe nature have a lower level of labour force participation than the population as a whole. Official ABS data from 1998 has this disparity in national labour force participation measured at 34.7 per cent to 63.3 per cent nationally and 32 per cent compared to 63.6 per cent for the Victorian population as a whole.

The operation divisions of Brite Industries are primarily plastics and packaging and a wholesale nursery business. The organisation's divisions are subcontract packaging, a wholesale retail nursery, garden property maintenance, vocational training and education and work/life skills education. Employees work together on a modern factory floor dealing with vacuum foaming and the latest thermoblasting equipment to wrap, pack and dispatch. At the end of June 2000, Brite had sales of up to $1.5 million. Brite Industries is an example to the rest of the community of a successful commercial model for integrating people with special needs and assisting them into open employment.

Brite has formed cooperative partnerships with private industry in the area, including Ford Australia. Ford, like many other manufacturing organisations in the city of Hume, work within a corporate citizenship program. This of course has benefited Brite with technical advice on plant layout, production and handling methods. This has helped improve productivity and occupational health and safety. I would like to think that the engagement between the two organisations also benefits Ford Australia. I was happy, following my visit to the factory site, to nominate this firm for the Prime Minister's employee of the year awards. As CEO, Mr Michael Alcock not only says but practises, `Australia will be judged one day on how we look after our disadvantaged, our aged and our disabled,' and of course how true that is.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 14 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Did Australia accept the provisions of Part II of the International Labour Convention No. 173 on Protection of Workers' Claims (Employers' Insolvency) Convention 1992 on 8 June 1994.

(2) On what dates, in what circumstances and with what results have there been subsequent communications between the Commonwealth Government and the governments of each State and Territory concerning the Convention.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. When the Keating Labor Government ratified Convention 173 in 1994, it accepted only Part II concerning Protection of Workers' Claims by Means of a Privilege, but not Part III concerning Protection of Workers' Claims by a Guarantee Institution. The terms of the Convention enable ratifying Member States to accept either Part II or Part III, or both Parts.

(2) The then Commonwealth Department of Industrial Relations advised the States and Territories on 1 July 1994 that Australia had formally ratified Convention 173 on 8 June 1994, and that Convention 173 would come into force in 12 months.

This advice followed correspondence from the then Minister for Industrial Relations, the Hon Laurie Brereton MP, to his State and Territory counterparts on 2 June 1994, which advised that the Commonwealth was proposing to ratify Part II of Convention 173 on the basis of compliance by the Commonwealth's law and practice.

Since July 1994, the Department has referred to Convention 173 in its routine correspondence with the States and Territories concerning Australia's reporting obligations relating to ILO Conventions, on the understanding that Convention 173 was ratified on the basis of Commonwealth law and practice alone. Consequently, there have been no substantive responses from the States and Territories.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 18 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) What progress has been made on the project to develop an Australian Standard for European STORZ-type coupling since the answer to question No. 2576 (Hansard, 28 June 2001, page 29091).
(2) During the NSW bushfires in December 2001 and January 2002 which of the fire-fighting teams from NSW and other States were equipped with STORZ-type hose couplings.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The project to develop an Australian standard for European STORZ-type coupling is dependent upon assistance from representatives of the fire services industry and, in particular, from the Australasian Fire Authorities Council.

The Australasian Fire Authorities Council (AFAC) has advised that, at its General Meeting on 13 August 2001, it accepted a recommendation from its Community Safety Strategy Group that AFAC withdraw support for the development of a standardised Australian hose coupling of up to 70 mm, as its member agencies now have in place coupling adaptors to enable inter-agency operations.

AFAC also advises that, since the NSW bushfires, it has requested each participating agency to prepare a detailed Tour Report covering all aspects of their involvement. From these agency reports, a national report will be prepared to critically analyse all aspects of the fire fighting operations. This will involve issues such as adaptor success.
The national Tour Report will be provided to the NSW Coroner and the NSW fire agencies, and will be considered at the next AFAC meeting to be held later in 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the revised budget in 2001-2002 for his Department's spending on appreciation of cultural diversity.
(2) From this allocation, what sums are allocated for (a) grants under the Living in Harmony initiative, (b) Living in Harmony administration and (c) the New Agenda for Multicultural Australia.
(3) What other specific items are funded under departmental output 2.4 and what sums are allocated for each such item in 2001-2002.
(4) What is the forward allocation for 2002-2003 for each item referred to in parts (2) and (3).

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (b) $0.998m, including Living in Harmony partnerships and public information strategy

(3) One specific and identifiable item is $0.351m funding for the Federation of Ethnic Communities' Councils of Australia. State and Territory Offices have approximately $5.100m and Central Office has a further $4.600m for other Output 2.4 activities.
(4) For items mentioned in part (2):
(a) $3.500m was committed for Living in Harmony in the 2001 Federal election, and is now subject to Budget deliberations.
(b) Administration costs for Living in Harmony is included in the $3.500m in (4)(a) above.
No significant funding changes are expected in 2002-03 for items mentioned in part (3).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) What is the revised Budget allocation in 2001-2002 for departmental spending on migrant settlement services in 2001-2002.

(2) From this allocation what sums are designated for (a) grants for Migrant Resource Centres, (b) grants under the Community Settlement Services Scheme, (c) assistance to refugees and humanitarian entrants under the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy, (d) his Department's settlement planning and information provision and (e) other items, if any.
(3) What is the forward allocation for 2002-2003 for each item referred to in part (2).

(4) In respect of the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS), what amount of the 2001-2002 Budget is allocated to (a) initial information and orientation assistance, (b) accommodation support, (c) household formation support, (d) proposers' support, (e) service providers' support, (f) community support for refugees and (g) early health assessment and intervention.
(5) How many refugees and humanitarian entrants received assistance under the IHSS in 2000-2001 and how many are estimated to receive such assistance in 2001-2002.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) $193.4m which includes settlement services (covered under both Administered and Departmental components of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs' budget) referred to in question 2 as well as Translating and Interpreting Services and Adult Migrant English Program - tuition.

(2) (a) $9.2m for Migrant Resource Centres, (b) $15.5m for Community Settlement Services Scheme, (c) $18.7m for Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy, (d) $5.2m for settlement planning and information provision and (e) $103.9m for the Adult Migrant English Program, $25.2m for translating and interpreting services and $15.7m for other settlement services costs.
(3) The forward allocations are not set at this stage however, they are expected to be similar to the current allocations.

(4) (a) $2.1m for initial information and orientation assistance, (b) $2.6m for accommodation support, (c) $1.8m for household formation support, (d) $0.2m for proposers' support, (e) $0.7m for service providers' support, (f) $0.2m for community support for refugees and (g) $2.6m for early health assessment and intervention. The balance of $8.5m is for refugee accommodation ($3.0m) and other departmental support services ($5.5m).

(5) In 2000-2001 4,900 refugee and humanitarian entrants received assistance under the IHSS. It is expected that between 5,600 - 6,500 refugee and humanitarian entrants will receive assistance under IHSS in 2001-2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many projects currently receive funding in NSW under (a) the Migrant Resource Centre program and (b) the Community Settlement Services Scheme.
(2) What is the estimated sum of Commonwealth funding that will be provided to these projects in 2001-2002.
(3) What is the additional extra cost to these projects in (a) 2001-2002 and (b) 2002-2003 as a result of the implementation of the revised Social and Community Services (SACS) Award in NSW.
(4) Will the Government provide additional funding to projects in NSW to assist them to meet their increased obligations under the Award; if so, what amount; if not, why not.

(5) If the Government does not propose to provide NSW projects with additional funding to cope with their award obligations, how will it ensure that (a) service operation hours are not reduced, (b) client caseloads are not cut and (c) staff classifications are not downgraded.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) In NSW there are currently (a) 13 Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs)/Migrant Service Agencies (MSAs) receiving core funding and (b) 133 projects receiving funding under the Community Settlement Services Scheme (CSSS).

(2) Funding provided to these projects by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) in 2001-2002 under the CSSS and as core funding for MRCs/MSAs is $10,330,627. We do not have information about current funding from other Commonwealth agencies for these organisations and could not obtain it in the time available.

(3) It is estimated that the extra cost to these projects will be on average (a) approximately $1,830 per project in 2001-2002, and (b) approximately a further $60 per project in 2002-2003, after a further increase of 3 percent to all pay rates on 28 November 2002. These estimates are based on a small sample of NSW CSSS grants and MRC/MSA core funding taking into consideration an average of the new pay scales for all community service worker grades.

(4) No. The Government is not able to provide additional funding to projects in NSW. Funds for this financial year are fully committed. CSSS grants provide a funding contribution for specific projects and are not allocated to fund social/community worker positions.

Core funding to MRCs/MSAs does not contain a specific amount for salaries. MRC/MSA management committees manage their budget, expenditure and employment of staff independently, and make their own operational decisions. On average, approximately 2 percent indexation per annum is applied to core funding to MRCs/MSAs.

(5) The Department will, where necessary, negotiate adjustments to current CSSS work programs in order to manage the impact of the award rise in NSW. These adjustments do not necessarily involve a reduction in service hours or a cut in client caseloads. The shortfall may be managed by some changes to the more discretionary aspects of their work programs and operational plans. While a small number of organisations have raised this issue with the Department, at this stage, no work programs have had to be adjusted.

Where an MRC/MSA is experiencing a shortfall in funding, it is the responsibility of the Committee of Management to consider operational options to manage this shortfall. Staff classification is a matter for the MRC/MSA committees of management, the employer, not DIMIA.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 21 February 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware that since 2 October 2001 the ship CSL Pacific registered in Nassau and manned by a Ukrainian crew has regularly carried cargoes of cement powder and associated products for Adelaide Brighton Cement on voyages from Port Adelaide to Melbourne, Sydney, Port Kembla and Brisbane.
(2) As the voyages are not part of an overseas voyage is he able to say whether the crew are illegal non-citizens without visas.
(3) Was CSL Pacific formerly registered in Australia and operated by an Australian crew who have now been replaced by illegal non-citizens.
(4) Is he able to say whether there are Australian seafarers available to work on CSL Pacific.
(5) Will he direct that all necessary steps be taken to ensure the deportation of the illegal non-citizens who constitute the crew of CSL Pacific.
(6) What steps will he take to ensure that illegal non-citizens are not engaged as crew on ships in Australian waters.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am aware that the ship has been in Australian waters since 2 October 2001, involved in the activities mentioned.
(2) The vessel is considered by the Australian Customs Service not to be imported. Therefore the crew are, by operation of law, holders of Special Purpose Visas and are not unlawful non-citizens.
(3) I am informed the CSL Pacific was formerly registered in Australia and operated by an Australian crew. The present crew hold Special Purpose Visas.
(4) I am unable to comment on the availability or otherwise of Australian seafarers.
(5) If any of the crew of this or any other ship were found to be unlawful non-citizens then the appropriate steps would be taken to ensure they depart Australia.
(6) Arrangements are already in place to ensure that unlawful non-citizens are not engaged on ships in Australian waters.
